questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the histology of the esophagus?

options.label: A
options.text: The upper third consists of smooth muscle, and the lower third is composed of striated muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: The adventitia is made up of dense connective tissue with blood vessels and nerves.

options.label: C
options.text: The middle third contains a mix of striated and smooth muscle fibers.

options.label: D
options.text: The entire esophagus is lined with keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.correct_answer: C. The middle third contains a mix of striated and smooth muscle fibers.

questions.text: Which among the following is the correct pairing of the part of the larynx to the structure from which it is derived?
questions.explanation:
Component

Derivation/Description

Lining Epithelium

Derived from endoderm

Cartilages
  • Epiglottis, thyroid, cuneiform cartilages: Derived from 4th pharyngeal arch
  • Cricoid, arytenoid, corniculate cartilages: Derived from 6th pharyngeal arch

Muscles

Derived from branchial mesoderm

  • All intrinsic muscles:
    • Develops from the 6th pharyngeal arch
    • Supplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve
  • Cricothyroid muscle:
    • Develops from the 4th pharyngeal arch
    • Supplied by external laryngeal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following structures of the larynx have seromucous glands? False vocal cord True vocal cord Ventricle Saccule
questions.explanation:
Structure

Histological Features

False Vocal Cord

Columnar ciliated respiratory-type epithelium with seromucous glands

True Vocal Cord

Stratified squamous epithelium

Ventricle

Respiratory-type columnar epithelium

Saccule

Respiratory-type columnar epithelium with seromucous glands

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient presents with difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) and nasal regurgitation of food. He also reports that his speech has become nasal and less clear. On examination, you notice that his soft palate does not elevate properly during swallowing, and there is an abnormal ridge in the nasopharynx. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Paralysis of the superior pharyngeal constrictor muscle

options.label: B
options.text: Damage to the glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX)

options.label: C
options.text: Weakness of the levator veli palatini muscle

questions.correct_answer: A. Paralysis of the superior pharyngeal constrictor muscle

questions.text: Mark the false statement about the structure being palpated here

options.label: A
options.text: Blood supply is by superior thyroid artery

options.label: B
options.text: Extends from C6-T6 in standing position

options.label: C
options.text: Lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium

options.label: D
options.text: Left recurrent laryngeal nerve lies posterior to it

questions.correct_answer: A. Blood supply is by superior thyroid artery
questions.explanation:
Structure
  • The trachea is a flexible fibrocartilaginous tube forming the start of the lower respiratory tract, supported by 16–20 C-shaped hyaline cartilage rings.

Function
  • The trachea remains open due to these cartilage rings, while the gap between the posterior ends is bridged by smooth muscle (trachealis) and fibroelastic ligament, allowing esophageal expansion during swallowing.

Location
  • Extends from the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (C6 vertebra) to the lower border of the T4 vertebra.
  • The upper half lies in the neck (cervical part)
  • Lower half in the superior mediastinum (thoracic part).

Variations
  • Cadaver (supine): C6 to T4
  • Living (standing): C6 to T6 (Option B ruled out)
  • Newborns: C6 to T3

Dimensions
  • Length: 10–12 cm
  • External diameter: 2 cm (males), 1.5 cm (females)
  • Internal diameter: 12 mm (adults), 3 mm (newborns)

Course
  • Begins as a continuation of the larynx at the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (C6 vertebra), descends behind the manubrium, and bifurcates into two bronchi at the lower border of T4, slightly to the right.

Relations

Anterior:

  • Arch of aorta
  • Brachiocephalic trunk
  • Left brachiocephalic vein
  • Superior vena cava

Posterior:

  • Esophagus
  • Left recurrent laryngeal nerve (Option D ruled out)
  • Vertebral column
  • Right: Azygous vein
  • Left: Arch of aorta, Left subclavian vein, Left phrenic nerve
  • On either sides: Lung and pleura, vagus nerve

Histology
  • Mucosa is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells (Option C ruled out)
 

Blood supply
  • Arterial supply: Inferior thyroid artery (Option A)
  • Venous drainage: Left brachiocephalic vein

Lymphatic drainage
  • Pretracheal and paratracheal nodes

questions.text: Patient who had suspected lung pathology was advised to undergo CT chest. While analysing the CT images, what vertebral level could this image likely correspond to?
questions.explanation:
Structure

Vertebral level
  • Cricoid cartilage
  • End of larynx & pharynx
  • Beginning of esophagus & trachea
  

C6
  • Tracheal bifurcation
  • Sternal angle (Angle of Louis)
  • Arch of aorta
  • Azygous vein drains into SVC
  

T4

(Option C)

Openings of diaphragm:

IVC opening

T8

Esophageal hiatus

T10

Aortic hiatus

T12

Constrictions of esophagus:

Pharyngo-esophageal junction (cervical)

C6

Arch of aorta crossing

T4

Crossing of Left principal bronchus

T6

Diaphragm opening

T10

questions.text: All of the following are true about structures related to the extent of larynx except

options.label: A
options.text: Extent of larynx in adult female is C3-C6

options.label: B
options.text: Bifurcation of common carotid occurs at superior border of thyroid cartilage

options.label: C
options.text: Cricoid is the lowermost cartilage of larynx

options.label: D
options.text: Extent of larynx in children is C1-C4

questions.correct_answer: A. Extent of larynx in adult female is C3-C6
questions.explanation:
Adult male

C3-C6

Adult female

C1-C4

(Option A)

Children

C1-C4

(Option D)

  Infant Larynx Adult Larynx

Position

Superiorly placed (C1-C4)

3rd -6th cervical vertebrae (C3-C6)

Epiglottis

Omega shaped, floppy

Leaf like

Narrowest area

Subglottis

Glottis

Submucosal tissue

More abundant

Less abundant

questions.text: Choose the appropriate set of incorrect statement(s) about the course of the marked nerve in image 1) Left sided nerve loops around arch of aorta 2) Travels anterior to the lung hilum 3) Originates from the lateral aspect of medulla 4) Runs within the carotid sheath with IJV laterally and ICA medially 5) Right nerve has a longer course than the Left.
questions.explanation:
Origin and common course
  • Exits from the lateral aspect of the medulla (Statement 3), posterior to the pontomedullary junction, and leaves the skull through the jugular foramen.
  • Runs within the carotid sheath with IJV laterally and ICA medially (Statement 4)
  • The right vagus has a shorter course than the Left (Statement 5)
 

Branches
  • Superior Laryngeal Nerve: Emerges in the neck and supplies the larynx, divides further into
    • Internal laryngeal nerve: Responsible for cough reflex
    • External laryngeal nerve: Supplies the Cricothyroid muscle
  • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerves:
    • Ascend from the brachiocephalic artery on the right and aortic arch on the left
    • Supplies all muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid

questions.text: Arterial supply of larynx is by

options.label: A
options.text: Superior laryngeal artery- branch of superior thyroid artery & inferior laryngeal artery- branch of inferior thyroid artery

options.label: B
options.text: Both superior and inferior laryngeal artery - branch of inferior thyroid artery

options.label: C
options.text: Both superior and inferior laryngeal artery - branch of superior thyroid artery

options.label: D
options.text: Superior laryngeal artery- branch of subclavian artery & inferior laryngeal artery- branch of inferior thyroid artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Superior laryngeal artery- branch of superior thyroid artery & inferior laryngeal artery- branch of inferior thyroid artery
questions.explanation:
Arterial supply:

Artery

Branch of

Superior laryngeal artery

Superior thyroid artery (branch of External carotid)

Inferior laryngeal artery

Inferior thyroid artery (branch of Thyrocervical trunk)

Cricothyroid artery (occasionally)

Superior thyroid artery (branch of External carotid)

Rima glottidis: Has dual blood supply (from both superior and inferior laryngeal)

Venous drainage:

Vein

Drains into

Superior laryngeal vein

Superior thyroid vein → Internal jugular vein

Inferior laryngeal vein

Inferior thyroid vein → Left Brachiocephalic vein

questions.text: What is the structure marked as X in the laryngoscopy diagram given below?

Match the intrinsic muscles of the vocal cord with its function Function Muscle a. Abduct the vocal cords 1. Aryepiglottic b. Tense the vocal cords 2. Posterior cricoarytenoid c. Close the inlet of the larynx 3. Cricothyroid d. Open inlet of larynx 4. Thyroepiglotticus
questions.explanation:
Function

Muscles

Abduct the vocal cords

Posterior cricoarytenoids (safety muscle of larynx)

Adduct the vocal cords
  • Lateral cricoarytenoids
  • Transverse arytenoid
  • Cricothyroids (tuning fork of larynx)
  • Thyroarytenoids

Tense the vocal cords

Cricothyroids

Relax the vocal cords
  • Thyroarytenoids
  • Vocalis

Close the inlet of the larynx
  • Oblique arytenoids
  • Aryepiglottic

Open the inlet of the larynx

Thyroepiglotticus

questions.text: Which of the following cartilages of the larynx is paired?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Shape

V-shaped in cross-section, with right and left laminae

Laminae

Roughly quadrilateral

Anterior Borders

Approach at an angle of about 90° in males, 120° in females.

Laryngeal Prominence

Formed by fusion of the lower parts of the anterior borders.

Thyroid Notch

Separates the upper parts of the anterior borders.

Superior Cornua (Horns)

Connected to the greater cornua of the hyoid bone by the lateral thyrohyoid ligament.

Inferior Cornua (Horns)

Articulates with the cricoid cartilage, forming the cricothyroid joint.

questions.text: From the sagittal section of the larynx given below, identify the part marked as X.
Arrange the structures of the pharynx in the correct sequential order from innermost to outermost.

options.label: A
options.text: Mucosa, Submucosa, Buccopharyngeal fascia, Pharyngobasilar fascia, Muscular coat

options.label: B
options.text: Mucosa, Submucosa, Muscular coat, Buccopharyngeal fascia, Pharyngobasilar fascia

options.label: C
options.text: Mucosa, Submucosa, Pharyngobasilar fascia, Muscular coat, Buccopharyngeal fascia

options.label: D
options.text: Mucosa, Submucosa, Buccopharyngeal fascia, Muscular coat, Pharyngobasilar fascia

questions.correct_answer: C. Mucosa, Submucosa, Pharyngobasilar fascia, Muscular coat, Buccopharyngeal fascia
questions.explanation:
Pharynx- Anatomy and parts
  • Muscular tube located behind the nose, mouth, and larynx, serving as a passage for both air and food.
  • Approximately 12 cm long, widest at the top, and narrowest at the bottom.

Boundaries of the Pharynx
  • Superiorly: Base of the skull
  • Inferiorly: Oesophagus (at the level of the sixth cervical vertebra)
  • Posteriorly: Prevertebral fascia
  • Anteriorly: Nasal cavity, oral cavity, and larynx
  • Laterally: Styloid process, carotid arteries, cranial nerves

Parts of the Pharynx
  • Nasopharynx: Behind the nose, connects to the middle ear via the pharyngotympanic tube. Primarily located at the C1 vertebral levels.
  • Oropharynx: Behind the oral cavity and corresponds to the C2 to upper part of C3 vertebral levels.
  • Laryngopharynx: Behind the larynx, it extends from the upper border of epiglottis to the cricoid cartilage's lower border. It corresponds to the C3 to C6 vertebral levels.

Structure of the Pharynx
  • Mucosa: Innermost layer.
  • Submucosa: Beneath the mucosa.
  • Pharyngobasilar fascia: Fibrous sheet thickest in the upper part, fills gap between the superior constrictor and the skull.
  • Muscular coat: Outer circular and inner longitudinal layers.
  • Buccopharyngeal fascia: Covers the constrictor muscles and extends forward to cover the buccinator.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) and is scheduled for an oesophagoscopy. During the procedure, the gastroenterologist must navigate the natural constrictions of the esophagus. At approximately 27.5 cm from the patient's incisor teeth, which anatomical structure is causing the narrowing?

A 45 year old male presents with difficulty swallowing and occasional regurgitation of undigested food. A barium swallow study is shown below. Esophageal manometry reveals impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). What is the most likely underlying cause of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of parasympathetic innervation from the recurrent laryngeal nerves

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperactivity of the sympathetic nerves from the upper thoracic ganglia

options.label: C
options.text: Degeneration of the esophageal plexus affecting peristalsis

options.label: D
options.text: Overactivity of the middle cervical ganglion fibres

questions.correct_answer: C. Degeneration of the esophageal plexus affecting peristalsis
questions.explanation:
Lymphatics and nerve supply of esophagus

Lymphatic Drainage
  • The lymphatic drainage of the esophagus varies by region
  • Cervical esophagus: Drains into the deep cervical lymph nodes.
  • Thoracic esophagus: Drains into the posterior mediastinal lymph nodes.
  • Abdominal esophagus: Drains into the left gastric lymph nodes.
  • Each section's lymphatic fluid is directed to nodes located in the neck, thorax, and upper abdomen.

Nerve Supply

The nerve supply of the esophagus involves both parasympathetic and sympathetic systems, enabling the control of swallowing and peristalsis.

  • Parasympathetic nerves:
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerves: Innervate the upper esophagus.
    • Esophageal plexus: Derived from the vagus nerve, it supplies the lower esophagus.
  • Sympathetic nerves:
    • Middle cervical ganglion: Provides fibers that accompany the inferior thyroid arteries to the upper esophagus.
    • Upper four thoracic ganglia: Supply the lower esophagus.

Clinical Significance
  • The esophageal plexus coordinates peristalsis and regulates the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), preventing reflux of stomach acid.
  • Disorders such as achalasia cardia, where the LES fails to relax, can cause difficulty in swallowing and food buildup in the esophagus. It occurs due to the absence of nerve cells in the esophageal wall.

questions.text: A 48 year old male with a long-standing history of alcohol-related liver cirrhosis presents to the ER department with hematemesis. On examination, icterus is seen and the abdomen is distended. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy confirms the presence of bleeding oesophageal varices at the lower end of the oesophagus. Which of the following vessels is primarily responsible for creating the portosystemic anastomoses that lead to the development of these varices?
questions.explanation:
Blood supply and drainage of esophagus

Arterial Supply
  • The esophagus receives arterial blood primarily from branches of the left gastric artery.
  • Additionally, different parts of the esophagus are supplied by:
    • Cervical esophagus: Inferior thyroid arteries.
    • Thoracic esophagus: Esophageal branches of the aorta.
    • Abdominal esophagus: Esophageal branches of the left gastric artery.

Venous Drainage
  • The esophagus drains into both the portal and systemic venous systems, forming portosystemic anastomoses.
    • Upper esophagus: Veins drain into the brachiocephalic veins. (Option C)
    • Middle esophagus: Veins drain into the azygos veins.
    • Lower esophagus: Veins drain into both the left gastric vein (portal system) and the azygos/hemiazygos veins (systemic system). (Option B)

Clinical Significance:
  • The portosystemic anastomoses at the lower end of the esophagus are crucial in conditions like portal hypertension.
    • In portal hypertension, the pressure in the portal venous system increases (commonly due to liver disease), causing the anastomoses to dilate.
    • This dilation leads to the formation of esophageal varices, which are fragile and can rupture, resulting in life-threatening bleeding (haematemesis).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the course of the esophagus in thorax and abdomen. The esophagus begins at the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. The esophagus enters the abdomen at the level of the T10 vertebra. The esophagus ends at the cardiac end of the stomach at T11 vertebra. The thoracic esophagus passes through the anterior mediastinum.
questions.explanation:
Course of esophagus

Origin

Begins at the lower border of the cricoid cartilage, connecting to the lower end of the pharynx. (Option C)

Course in the Neck

Travels downward in front of the vertebral column.

Thoracic Course

Passes through the superior and posterior mediastinum in the thorax. (Option C)

Diaphragmatic Passage

Passes through the esophageal hiatus at the level of T10 vertebra, slightly left of the midline. (Option C)

Abdominal Course
  • Becomes the abdominal esophagus, approximately 1.25 cm long, moves downward and left.
  • Lies in front of the left crus of the diaphragm and inferior surface of the left lobe of the liver.

Termination

Ends at the cardiac end of the stomach at T11 vertebra, about 2.5 cm to the left of the midline. (Option C)

Clinical Significance
  • Oesophageal hiatus transmits the gastric nerves, esophageal branches of the left gastric artery, and veins.
  • Veins draining the esophagus form portosystemic anastomoses, creating connections between portal and systemic venous systems.
  • Portal hypertension can cause esophageal varices, which may rupture and lead to haematemesis (severe bleeding).

questions.text: A 8 year old child presents to the pediatric clinic with recurrent ear infections and complaints of ear pain, especially after upper respiratory infections. What is the most likely reason for this child's increased susceptibility to ear infections?

options.label: A
options.text: The Eustachian tube's shorter length allows for quicker drainage of secretions from the middle ear.

options.label: B
options.text: The more horizontal orientation of the Eustachian tube in children impairs proper ventilation and drainage of the middle ear.

options.label: C
options.text: The Eustachian tube opens more frequently during normal activities in children, causing increased exposure to environmental allergens.

options.label: D
options.text: The Eustachian tube is typically narrow in children, which facilitates the entry of pathogens from the nasopharynx.

questions.correct_answer: B. The more horizontal orientation of the Eustachian tube in children impairs proper ventilation and drainage of the middle ear.
questions.explanation:
Eustachian Tube/ Pharyngotympanic tube/ Auditory tube

Provides communication between middle ear and exterior; maintains equal air pressure; opens during swallowing, yawning, sneezing with help from tensor and levator veli palatini muscles

 

Characteristics
  • Shape: Trumpet-shaped
  • Length: Approximately 4 cm
  • Direction: Downward, forward, and medially
  • Angles: 45° with the sagittal plane, 30° with the horizontal plane
  • Parts: Bony part, cartilaginous part

Bony Part
  • Length: 12 mm
  • Location: Lies in the petrous temporal bone near the tympanic plate.

Cartilaginous Part
  • Length: 25 mm
  • Location: Lies in the sulcus tubae between greater wing of the sphenoid and apex of petrous temporal

Vascular Supply
  • Arterial Supply: Ascending pharyngeal artery, middle meningeal arteries, artery of the pterygoid canal
  • Venous Drainage: Pharyngeal and pterygoid plexuses
  • Lymphatic Drainage: Retropharyngeal nodes

Nerve Supply
  • Pharyngeal branch of the pterygopalatine ganglion at the ostium;
  • Nervus spinosus branch of the mandibular nerve (cartilaginous part);
  • Tympanic plexus from the glossopharyngeal nerve (bony part)

Clinical Significance
  • Infections: Can spread from throat to middle ear; more common in children due to shorter, wider, straighter Eustachian tube. (Option B)
  • Eustachian Catarrh: Inflammation from colds or sore throats can block the tube, causing ear pain, especially during swallowing; enlargement of the tubal tonsil may obstruct the ostium in children

questions.text: A 32 year old male involved in smuggling accidentally swallowed a foreign object, which became lodged in his piriform fossa. After its removal, he reports numbness and loss of sensation in his throat. Which nerve is most likely damaged during the procedure?

Match the spaces between the constrictor muscles with the structures that pass through them: Spaces Structures 1) Sinus of Morgagni A) Internal laryngeal nerve, superior laryngeal vessels 2) Space between superior and middle constrictors B) Recurrent laryngeal nerve, inferior laryngeal vessels 3) Space between middle and inferior constrictors C) Stylopharyngeus muscle, glossopharyngeal nerve 4) Space below the inferior constrictor D) Auditory tube, levator veli palatini muscle, ascending palatine artery, palatine branch of ascending pharyngeal artery
questions.explanation:
Constrictors muscles and the spaces between them

Constrictor Muscles of the Pharynx

Form the outer circular layer and overlap each other.

  • Superior Constrictor:
    • Originates from the pterygoid hamulus, pterygomandibular raphe, mandible, and the side of the posterior tongue.
    • Its upper border is attached to the base of the skull, leaving a space called the sinus of Morgagni, filled by the pharyngobasilar fascia.
  • Middle Constrictor:
    • Overlaps the lower part of the superior constrictor.
    • Originates from the stylohyoid ligament, lesser cornua, and the upper border of the greater cornua of the hyoid bone.
    • The stylopharyngeus muscle and glossopharyngeal nerve pass through the gap between the superior and middle constrictors.
  • Inferior Constrictor:
    • Overlapping the middle constrictor.
    • Composed of two parts:
      • Thyropharyngeus: Originates from the oblique line of the thyroid cartilage.
      • Cricopharyngeus: Originates from the cricoid cartilage.
    • The internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels pass through the gap between the middle and inferior constrictors.

All three constrictor muscles attach to the median raphe at the posterior pharyngeal wall. The top of this raphe connects to the pharyngeal tubercle at the skull base, while the lower edge of the inferior constrictor blends with the esophagus' circular muscle.

Spaces Between the Constrictor Muscles

(Option A)

The overlapping nature of these muscles forms spaces through which nerves and blood vessels pass:

 


  • Sinus of Morgagni (between the superior constrictor's upper border and the skull base):
    • Allows the passage of the auditory tube, levator veli palatini muscle, ascending palatine artery, and the palatine branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery.
  • Space between the superior and middle constrictors:
    • Contains the stylopharyngeus muscle and glossopharyngeal nerve.
  • Space between the middle and inferior constrictors:
    • Contains the internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels.
  • Space below the inferior constrictor:
    • Contains the recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels.

Killian's Dehiscence
  • Location: At the lower part of the posterior pharyngeal wall, below the vocal folds and above the cricopharyngeal sphincter.
  • Clinically significant area as it is a weak point. (Thyropharyngeus muscle is not reinforced internally by other constrictors)
  • The area is often associated with the formation of pharyngeal diverticula.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves supplies motor fibres to all pharyngeal muscles except the stylopharyngeus?
questions.explanation:
Muscles of pharynx and nerve supply

Muscles of the Pharynx
  • Divided into two layers:
    • Outer circular layer
    • Inner longitudinal layer
  • Constrictor muscles: Form the outer circular layer and overlap each other:
    • Superior constrictor
    • Middle constrictor
    • Inferior constrictor: Has two parts:
      • Thyropharyngeus
      • Cricopharyngeus
  • Longitudinal muscles: Form the inner longitudinal layer:
    • Stylopharyngeus: From the styloid process to the inner surface of the middle and inferior constrictors.
    • Palatopharyngeus: From the palate, running down the inner side of the constrictors.
    • Salpingopharyngeus: From the auditory tube, merging with the palatopharyngeus.

Nerve Supply

The pharynx is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus (located on the middle constrictor), which includes:

  • Vagus nerve: Carries fibers from the cranial accessory nerve.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve
  • Superior cervical sympathetic ganglion
  • Motor fibers: Supplied by the cranial accessory nerve via vagus nerve branches (except the stylopharyngeus, supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve). (Option C)
  • Sensory fibers: Mostly from the glossopharyngeal nerve, partly from the vagus nerve.
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibers: From the lesser palatine branches of the pterygopalatine ganglion.
